title: Four Seasons rescue plan on the brink of collapse
text:
The parent companies of Four Seasons, which houses around 16,000 residents, tumbled into administration earlier this year

Fresh fears have been raised over the future of Four Seasons Health Care, as the planned rescue of more than half its care homes fell apart.

The parent companies of Four Seasons, which houses around 16,000 elderly residents, tumbled into administration earlier this year under the weight of a £625million debt pile.

Hedge fund H/2 Capital Partners, which had been a major lender to the troubled business, was planning to buy around 185 of the 320-strong estate, providing much-needed security for the group's vulnerable residents.

But that deal was shattered last night as the administrators, Alvarez & Marsal, announced details of the agreement had not been met.

Four Seasons would not provide clarity on which conditions were to blame. The chain remains in discussions with its landlords, who own the remainder of its 320 care homes.

It stopped paying rent to the landlords earlier this month in an attempt to draw them to the negotiating table, claiming the bills it was paying them are unsustainable.

Four Seasons has paid more than £100million in rent over the last two years, and an independent report found that a majority of the landlords are charging above market rate.

The landlords include controversial investment firm Cerberus Capital Management, which has been branded a 'hound of hell' by MPs for its role in buying up household debt from banks and wringing borrowers for repayment.

Martin Healy, chairman of Four Seasons, said last night: 'All parties remain in constructive discussions.

'The priority of everybody involved remains entirely focused on continuing to provide high quality care for our residents and patients in this next phase of the restructuring.'

Four Seasons will continue talks with its landlords in the hope of lowering rents to more sustainable levels.
